- Salmon entree

THE FOOD: The salmon entree came with fresh tortillas, rice, beans, and the most amazing (though spicy!) sauce. Hands down AMAZING. The guac was super yummy, slightly pricey, but surprisingly filling. I'd stick with just the shrimp ceviche.

BUT: My friend and I were here on a Sunday night, and it took 2 hours to get all our food and eat! Service was super slow, the food took forever to get to the table, but since we weren't in a hurry and had a lot to talk about, it was fine. 

Great place!
author: Amanda L.

description:
We were in the Union Square area shopping and needed to grab a quick bite so we ventured to Tropisueno.  I ordered the pork skewers and the gf had a taco and enchilada plate.  

I ate the pastor taco and it was pretty good.  The tortilla was soft and actually had flavor to it and the pastor was well seasoned and juicy.  The enchilada didn't seem to be as good.  Gf said it tasted like string cheese wrapped in a tortilla.  Too bad for her...

The real standout of the meal were the free chips (greased and crisped perfectly) and the roasted habanero salsa that came with my pork skewers.  It had just the right amount of heat and the roasted pepper flavor was quite superb.  

And although I usually don't like margaritas my house margarita was also very good.  I couldn't taste the alcohol at all, but I knew it was there.  Like the menu says, it was really deceiving.

Prices were also very reasonable.

Would recommend.
author: J K.

description: Tasty food in a busy and noisy place. Came here for lunch after contemporary Jewish museum.  Fun salsa bar.
author: Lisa G.

description:
Amazing.

I went here for the montly date night with my girlfriend. The bill was $50 but it was spectacular to the point that I left a $10 tip.

We ordered to of the mitzuso or something margaritas. They were a bit too spicy for my GF and they swapped it out for the house margarita and gave me her reject so I got a free $9 rita.

We ordered the favoritos 3 entree combo and it was authentic, tasty and super fast turnaround considering the restaurant was full!

We enjoyed ourself, the atmosphere was great and the price was perfect considering how amazing the service was and how authentic the food was.

I can't wait to go back when I save up enough money to go.
author: Adam C.

description:
$5 Margaritas with 100% blue agave tequila at happy hour? I'm in. M-F 4-6 pm. 

Salsa & chips are always free. Guacamole was fresh and chunky. Ceviche was really tasty with fresh fish and good size cuts. I will ask what kind of fish it was. I think the guac and ceviche were like $3 or $5.

The shrimp cocktail came in what looked like a cold soup and was ok. Seemed a little overpriced. Food from the regular menu looked good enough to come back and try.

The new chef came by to see how everything was. Glad to see they are taking an interest in quality and improvement. Definitely coming back. Hope they solidify the happy hour menu items or try a few different things.
author: Eric P.

description:
The chips were the best part of the meal, light and crispy, dare I say shockingly delicate.  The plantains and black beans, drizzled in this delicious creamy white sauce, were a close second. 
And then we were ready to get served real food, and thats where the deductions began.  The pollo asado was on the blander side, dry and more akin to indian tandoori than one would expect from a "mexican kitchen".  The albondigas stew, which was advertised as a velvety dish, was disappointingly watery and overpowered with flavors of cilantro and cloves.  That being said, the meatballs in the "stew" were hearty and tasty.  The big winner of the night was the chili verde.  Portion-wise and flavor-wise the pork was completely satisfying.  Prepare to ask for more tortillas unless you feel that three is adequate.  The house margaritas felt dinky in both quality and quantity for their $8 price.
Overall, the experience was enjoyable thanks to the contributions of the chips, the beans and the festive decor.
author: Bita H.

description: Went to this place because it was near my hotel and was craving mexican, not bad not bad. If you're looking for authentic, then head to the Mission though. This place was more expensive, but it was really good. The mole was tasty, the salsas were great, and the tacos were very nice. Like I said, everything was good, but its not street food Mexican, which is the best.
author: Nicolette H.

description:
Went here at like 7pm on a Friday night...didn't even have to wait for a table and they were very prompt about bringing out our drinks (a much-needed margarita!!). The strawberry margarita was delicious!! 

They have complimentary chips and salsa...they are fresh and tasty.

Our entrees were all yummy. I got a combo w/ an enchilada, a taco, and a flauta, and they all tasted great. I wasn't a huge fan of their rice, but everything else was great! It was somewhat expensive (around $80 for 3 people, including drinks), but I think fairly priced.

The ambiance was perfect for dinner and drinks, casual, but still nice and intimate. I hope I can go back soon :)
author: Nicole A.

description: Fantastic quality food and a great atmosphere. Upscale Mexican with a variety of dishes. Staff was very attentive to our needs and adapted dishes to our low-carb needs without any problems, although the server who actually delivered the food seemed confused about the lack of rice/tortillas.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
Tropisueno was such a relief. As a new Soma resident, our yelp suggested adventures have been hit and miss, but Tropisueno pleased and surprised us throughout the night. 

First off, chips and salsa=clutch. Freshly made warm chips and two different salsa options were a nice change from the typical stale chips and gloppy red concoctions at chain restaurants. 

The entrees aren't just good mexican food, they actually taste too good to be mexican food. Whenever I am in the mood for Mexican, I am craving greasy and sloppily assembled street food full of flavor- but definitely not fine dining. This place served us exquisitely prepared food, with all the fun flavor of a taco truck. The ingredients were fresh, the tortillas delicious, and all of the meat was juicy and well seasoned. I had the pork and it almost melted in my mouth. My girlfriend had a two taco combo platter with one chicken and one beef and was definitely satisfied (only 10.95!) We also both noticed that for the first time at a mexican restaurant we both thought everything on our plate was delicious! The beans were great and the rice tasted fluffy and perfectly seasoned (not too spicy or tomato-ey.) In short, every bite was great.

BONUS- they serve you lollipops with your check which is the perfect thing to satisfy your sweet craving after a rich and salty meal.
author: Nate M.

description:
Wonderful service!  Their taco appetizer was delish!  Their salsas were good.  Their carne asada skirt steak was a bit too salty for me but the rest of our meal was great!

I think this will be my new place for nicer mexican food since it's close to my house and the service was so pleasant and made me so happy.
author: Becca L.

description:
I've been to Tropisueño five times in the last two weeks. Four were for lunch and one was for after work drinks. The first time I ate here was dinner a few weeks after the restaurant opened last year.

I love how Tropisueño is two restaurants in one. At lunchtime, the garage door is open and it's pretty much a taqueria. In the evening, the garage door is closed and there is more formal dinner service.

The complimentary chips are awesome. Nice and thin. Come here during lunch so you can have the chips with a wide range of condiments.

The carnitas (I had it with a super taco) were a revelation. They come in chunks as opposed to shredded. Great flavor.

You can get out of here at lunch for less than $10. One item (enchilada, tamale, chile relleno, or taco) with rice, choice of beans, and a small salad will run you $6.95 (not incl. tax). Wash your lunch down with a Mexican Coke ($2.25).
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
A nice place to go when you're feeling a lil' classier than Chevy's, but want something at essentially the same price... great food, nice atmosphere, convienent central location

I had the beef tacos and the chicken enchilada... I agree with Poochie, we need some carnitas on the menu... but their available selection was tasty nonetheless

The waiter was a bit stern... kind of a, don't f#$k with me attitude... but other than that, I'd recommend it if you're in the area and too tired to make it out to the mission... although if you happen to be in that area (like, for instance, you needed to pick up your fix of heroin at 16th and Mission)... there are probably better options around
author: Ryan K.

description: Salsa selection and taste is great, but the rice and beans are just average.  Was expecting much more with the review but turns out not the case.
author: Jay H.

description:
I've been here twice now and will go back. The food is fairly priced, tasty, and prompt. The drinks are very good, especially the margaritas, no sickeningly sweet margaritas- they are smoky, tangy and refreshing.

The mushroom empanadas were done well, gooey and warm inside, lots of flavor. They tasted even better with fresh guacamole. The chips are also really tasty, lightly salted and very light and crispy. I am addicted.

The scallops are my favorite dish, I didn't really like the poc chuc (pork dish), the meat was dry and quite flavorless. Finally, the mole is just okay, it's done just alright but the beans that go with the mains are actually quite good as is the rice.

Overall, it's a great place to go with groups, just make sure that if you are celebrating a birthday and you ask them to cut a cake for you, that you ask them about a cake cutting fee. They tried charging us $17.50 without telling us ahead of time about the fee. They did remove it after I brought it to their attention so we made sure to tip our surly waiter a little extra for losing the higher check average. The manager wasn't the friendliest either but very professional. I will go back. The place closes early during the week though so  call ahead and see if they'll still sit you down.
author: Cristy J.

description:
We ate here again, and it's now dubbed the Yelp Cafeteria. Ha!

I had a fish taco and carnitas street taco this time, and both were yummy. The fish was a fried tilapia and at $4, it seemed a bit pricey, but it was actually quite filling.  

We aren't big enough to have a campus like Google (yet!) but if we have one, we're going to have to put a Tropisueño there. Googlers can keep Andale.
author: Connie C.

description:
I must say that I'm very impressed with Tropisueno.  

Whomever decorated Tropisueno was wonderfully talented and detail oriented.  They made unbelievable use of texture and color, including salvaged woods and fabulous live plants.  It felt authentically Mexican without being kitschy.  

Table service was nearly flawless.  We were seated immediately and our drinks were on the table before we could make up our minds about our food.

The fresh chips and salsa were so fantastic that it was hard to save room for dinner. I had the chile verde and Steve got Tampiqueno, a carne asada variant.  The pork in my chile verde was mouth watering, moist on the inside and sticky/crispy on the outside.  In otherwords, it was perfect!  Steve's was tasty but mine was better.  Both came with hot fresh tortillas, beans and rice.

And now for the coup de grace:  the house margarita.  I fully realize that I may be struck by lightning for the blasphemy I'm about to commit.  The Tropisueno Margarita de la Casa was better than margaritas at Tommy's.  There I said it and I'm not going to take it back.  

Two entrees and two margaritas:  $48 --entirely reasonable!
author: Amy A.

description: We've had lunch here a couple of years back, enjoying the freshness of the dishes and an amazing salsa bar.  This time, four of us for dinner, not so much.  Waitperson aggressively talked me out of a featured dish, salmon with ancho chile ("We can't tone it down for you."  Did I look  heat-phobic?).  So, ordered pork 3 ways--Each way tasted blandly the same.  Others in the group were similarly under-impressed by smallish portions as well unexceptional flavors.  Also: crowded, noisy, hard to get servers' attention.  We won't be back.
author: Robert G.

description: nice atmosphere, delicious margaritas, authentic tacos with well prepared meat, and the salsa bar has a nice habanero sauce that hits the spot. the only reason i don't give this place more stars is that amazingly, it's still not as good as the taco truck in front of the courthouse...
author: Sherman L.

description: Don't have the $ to hit Cabo? In one hour, listen to some authentic Mexican polka on the radio, indulge the salsa bar and you MUST have a house margie/I prefer mine with Heradura and pay the upcharge but their house T is fine! If you are lucky  the Honduran girls will be celebrating a birthday and Mr. Cuevas or Ms. Jesse will be pouring....feel at home here!! ANDAHLEEEEEEE
author: Carl K.

description: I love this place! While the service is not great, the food is awesome and they have great happy hour drinks (deeeelicious mojitos and margaritas). Definitely leave yourself plenty of time and be sure to make a reservation.
author: Sarah F.

description:
YuuuUM. This place has got the best meatball soup I've ever had. Have I ever had meatball soup before? Probably not. But that's not the point, the point is their meatball soup is amazing. The spices give it a great flavor, then throw in delicious meat and you've got yourself a dish you're going to enjoy. 

And the chips, as written ad nauseum, are delicious. Fresh and crispy accompanied by a tasty salsa. The ambiance is ok. Typical mid-level Mexican style décor (think red tiles on the floor, cream walls and high end Christmas lights). Not high end but festive.  The service is spectacular. As a big group, we were a difficult bunch for the waiter to handle. He, nonetheless, was friendly and attentive and did a great job. 

Lastly, the margaritas are great. I wish we could have ordered it by the pint but maybe it was for the best  given our 'race to the finish' tendencies with pints. Definitely check this place out - great food, great service and reasonably priced.
author: Shreya C.

description:
On a normal day, I would give Tropisueno 4 star, but my last couple experiences have led much to be desired. The past 2 times I went here, went to lunch with my friend (chile rellenos was a bit undercooked.. making it hard to eat and not exactly as delicious as I remembered it) and also went to a graduation dinner here for a friend. 

At my friend's graduation is where service knocked it down a star. First, we arrived early since we had a late reservation. We went to the bar area and was given MASSIVE attitude by the bartender. We ordered drinks for about 6 people and we kept on asking them if they had crowne, they didn't but they had remy (a pricier remy?). We decided to get 2 remy and cokes and they were whispering behind the bar area (we could still here them though) about whether or not this one bartender had informed us if it was pricier or not. The other bartender then replies to the other guy that "they didn't ask. so its on them." WHAT????? really. We honestly didn't care but the fact that they were talking so LOUDLY about it made the experience worse. At dinner, food also came at different times and we didn't get our sides until much later and what not. Either way, the food is still good, but they really need to shore up on their service. I would def. go back to them for lunch, but not for dinner.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
their burritos are huuge!!! and reeli awesome!
dinner options not so awesome if you happen to be a vegetarian!
nice place to dine with friends.. make sure to get a big bowl of their really yummy guac
author: Aditya M.

description:
Quaint place for lunch.  

Service is fast.  

I've tried 90% of the offerings on their menu. All very tasty and filling.  

The burrito is massive, so don't try to finish it in one sitting or you'll be in a food coma for the rest of the day!
author: Jeff H.

description:
I found this restaurant on the Opentable list. The restaurant is really cute, the set up is nice, not like your typical "Mexican" restaurant. The staff is really friendly and they all look happy. The house margaritas are really good (and strong), the guacamole was fresh and spicy, the chips were warm, thin and fresh and the salsas they gave us were both really good. For apps we got the Tostada de Camarones and Empanadas de Hongons. OMG soooo good. For entree we ordered, the 2 item combo (taco and enchilada both beef), really good, the beef is fresh and seasoned well, the Mexican rice is really good and also so are the white beans. The Tampiqueno, and the Camarones Tropisueno were really good. And to top it off for desert the chocolate fondue it comes with strawberries, pineapples, cinnamon chips and mexican yogurt. 
I would def come back here, it's a little pricey but they're happy hour looked like a awesome deal.
author: Irma R.

description: I love this place. I walked into the bar last night, it was totally crowded and I needed space for 3.   Carlos was quick on the draw and worked with me to get a few seats by letting me know who was leaving first.  All of the staff and bartenders are nice, attentive, enthusiastic and super cool.  The food was excellent (the scallops were off the chain) and their margaritas, free of cane sugar and sweet & sour, were addicting.  (made w/ agave nectar, lime & tequila only).  I love the enviroment, it feels festive, intimate, and authentic.  I'll be back again, even if by myself because I know Carlos or Ramon or someone who works there will keep me company!
author: Nikki H.

description: I love the HH here! What is not to love? Cheap prices, check! Strong homemade margs, check! No fake sweet and sour mixer anywhere to be found, check! Free chips and 3 different salsas, quadruple check!...I even heard they have a burrito bar at lunch--Must try it out soon.
author: Caitlin R.

description: My new favorite place to eat in SF and Roman is my new favorite bartender! We came here based on the Yelp reviews and we were not disappointed. The chips were light and crispy with a huge portion of guacamole. We ordered 3 street tacos each - a variet of carnitas, al pastor, and grilled shrimp - and again, the portions were so huge we could have gotten away with a few less tacos and still had been full. We also ordered the house margaritas which are made with agave syrup, no fake stuff so it tasted very fresh. We sat at the bar and Roman was very attentive, had great suggestions on drinks, and a great personality! We enjoyed our entire experience at Tropiseuno - you need to check it out!
author: LuLu M.

description: I have been here 3 times since it's in my hood and when I get a Mexican craving, Tropisueno never disappoints. The chips and salsa are very fresh and they also give you 3 more types of salsa if you crave more heat. The chicken enchilada in red sauce, the tamale in green sauce, and the flautas are my favorites. The margarita and strawberry margaritas are excellent - no margaritas mixes used here. We had an Asian waiter and his level of service impressed me and my date - attentive but not in your face every 5 minutes. I will definitely be back.
author: Kevin C.

description:
I am giving this restaurant a two star because I don't like being rushed thru my meal! Its my biggest no no! 
My husband was still eating actually putting a spoonful of food in his mouth and was asked may I take your plate! Thus happened multiple times! Grrrr I hate that! The food was ok not great but it might have been better if ever 10 minutes we were not asked to basically hurry the hell up! I understand the idea of turn over but man it was a little ridiculous! I won't go back that is for sure! If your looking for a relaxing Mexican dining expierience and to enjoy a few drinks don't go here your glass will be practically riped out of your hand when its half empty! 
To be fair the chips and salsa were great and we got to enjoy that because it was left on the table. And we shared the pork and pineapple tacos that was an interesting mix but was tasty! As for the rest of the meal I was much to rushed to enjoy it!
author: Mia B.

description: I have since been back on a recent road trip back down to So Cal from Portland. My picky eater of a husband LOVED this place! Put that in your pipe...(!!!)  2 thumbs way up!
author: HEATHER T.

description: Great Restuarant.  I found it on yelp when looking for a restaurant in union square and I hight recommend it!  The compilimentary chips with three salsa choices were delicious!  The house margarita packs a punch!  Both the chicken mole and the steak tampiqueno are exquisitley flavored with generous portions.  And they use Niman beef and Petaluma free range chicken!  I can't wait to go back and bring friends!
author: kristina a.

description:
Twice in one week! 

Tropisueño is located behind the gigantic Westfield Shopping Center on Market Street and tucked in a walkway near the Jewish Museum. I would have never known this place even existed it it weren't for yelp because I've never walked down that way and now I am so glad that I did. 

Things that are great about Tropisueño

-Tasty and Strong Margaritas 
-Full Bar 
-Amazing Chips with equally amazing salsas 
-Delicious Guac 
-Clean and Private Bathroom 
-Some of the best damn empanandas I have ever had. Three cheese, mushrooms, and topped with guac. 
-Reasonable drink prices 
-A Bartender that secretly listens in to you and two other guys play a game of "Would you rather" that was one of the sickest discussions I've ever had in my life.  
-Said bartender jokes with us about cutting us off after all the inappropriate talk 
-Food is inexpensive and tasty 

I'm really excited to have found Tropisueño tucked away in the alley and I know I will be back soon.
author: Nerd A.

description:
Food was delicious! It's in a part of town that tends to be overrun by tourists and bad food, but this is great food. It's a very authentic menu, and everything we had was delicious. We had the margaritas (to die for!), the homemade chips & salsa, the plantains appetizer, the mahi-mahi, and the tampiqueno..and it was all delicious! Plus they give you chuppa chups with your bill..which makes them even more awesome!

Bueno: Delicious food, authentic margaritas (no mix), decent sized seating area, great service, authentic mexican (don't come here for a taco - come for mole!)

Malo: no (cheap) parking anywhere nearby, margaritas are a tad small, bar area isn't huge
author: Sarah K.

description: Great Mexican food.  Famous salsa bar.  Line starts forming at 11:30 AM, but you can see why.
author: Erik K.

description:
Crowded and lively on a Saturday night, we were glad to have made reservations. Decor is festive. Group of 4 was seated promptly, and immediately delivered a huge bowl of fresh tortilla chips and two kinds of salsa (verde and fresca, I believe). The salsas were a bit bland for our tastes, so we asked if they had anything hotter. WOAH. The habenero salsa is to DIE for, and might just be the death of you if heat isn't your cup of tea. Use sparingly at first, unless you're used to extreme heat. But that salsa takes the prize! 

First off, Fried Plantains. Crispy on the outside, soft and sweet on the inside with creamy black beans. We also started with a round of house margaritas. They are $9, but tangy and strong(er than average). Meal was a two item combination for me - carne asada taco served more traditionally on two small tortillas with lots of cilantro and onion- and chili relleno smothered in cheese and just enough batter to still taste the pepper. Accompanied by subtly spicy Mexican rice. For $10 it was SO MUCH DELICIOUS FOOD! 

Three bowls of beans were brought to the table. Black, white and re-fried. Black beans were a bit watery, white beans were outrageously salty, but re-fried were creamy and rich. Interesting concept anyway, to bring all three. 

Everyone was satisfied with their food and for the price, in this area of town, knew that the quality could not be beat. Our waiter did forget to bring drinks out, and needed to be reminded and never offered a second round of margaritas. Otherwise, the service was friendly and prompt.
author: Jenni D.

description:
I came here twice in one week.  Both times I was pleased with my food.  Being downtown, it's nice to have a wallet friendly option.  From looking at the website and Yelp, you'd think that this place had table service.  Instead you order your food and pay at the counter.  Then take your number to your table and wait for it to be delivered.  Because of this, the menu prices are kept reasonable versus paying $15+ for a lunchtime meal.

The self serve condiments station has various salsas and other garnishings.  The mild salsa is really great with the fresh chips that they make.

On my first visit, I had the fish tacos.  These hit the spot and were exactly what I was looking for in flavor.  My second visit I had the super veggie quesadilla.  I don't feel like my quesadilla was loaded with veggies so I'm curious to see what the regular veggie quesadilla has in it.  As far as I can tell the only main difference is that the super comes with guacamole.

There's also a full service bar which I can't wait to try during happy hour.  

I haven't rated this place five stars because both times my order took awhile to be brought to my table since they had to make them in back.  Burritos and tacos are made up front and service is much faster.
author: Jessica C.

description: The food is decent. I loved the service until they started rushing us off of our table. We were interrupted way too many times for our own comfort. I love the atmosphere and the drinks but its not a good place to go if you want to have a conversation with someone. borderline rude!
author: Tia J.

description: My wife, daughter and I happened upon this place during a recent trip to San Francisco.  We were walking around and the chips alone caught my eye.  There was something about them that just looked good, homemade and thought out.  Then we noticed the line, which is usually a good sign.  I had the Mole Carnitas, wife had barbacoa and daughter had carnitas tacos.  Everything was about the best we've ever had - beans, rice, chips and every single salsa they had was unique and great.  Tropisueño is on our go to list for sure every time we return to SF.
author: J. Nathaniel B.

description: I love this place... And it's orange salsa. We sat at the bar the other night with Remy. He was amazing. Made the night a lot of fun
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
On my way out the door my dining companion asked me "on a scale of 1 to 10 what would you rate this place?" Without hesitation I gave it a 4 rating. Not four stars but a 4 at the lower end of the scale. 

What mystifies me about this place is the atmosphere. Are they trying to be a take out restaurant or sit down and serve. Obviously they are doing a combination of both but to me it begs complete waiter service. 

I chose the torta and well I have no idea why. It was the panini style version of a chicken quesadilla just more bread. Dining companion ordered a whole wheat quesadilla he got a flour tortilla quesadilla. White wine was terrible and the glass had a big ole chip in it and it took what seemed like forever to have my glass of wine rung up. 

I just think this place is your standard taqueria with dress up clothes. It's what it is but really could have a show of its own with the right tweaks to the script. 

Good luck.
author: Scott P.

description: We had such an incredible meal at Tropisueno for a friend's birthday! Some of the best service I've received at a restaurant in a long time. Everyone was incredible caring and thoughtful. It's one of our absolute favorite Mexican restaurants in all of SF!
author: Kaity W.

description:
Went back again (for lunch) and sat at the bar. Still a solid 4 stars.

The cocktail program rivals what you'd find at Beretta or Bourbon and Branch. Manual has a handcrafted tequila cocktail list that is fabulous. We had 4 or 5 drinks (a leisurely lunch) and thoroughly enjoyed each one.
(and as much as I love tequila it takes a lot for me to embrace it in cocktail form -- most drinks are overly sweet. Not here; a perfect balance of tequila and quality ingredients).
author: Margie L.

description:
One recommendation- MAKE RESERVATIONS early! 

My friends and I got back to our hotel (around 6)and were hoping to go for dinner at 7 on a Saturday. The earliest time we could get reservations for was 9:30. Even though we were starving we decided to wait because this restaurant came highly recommended by several people. That and I think we were all just salivating at the thoughts of yummy Mexican food- so yes we went in with very very high expectations. Tropisueno did not disappoint and was worth the wait! We got there about 9 and sat at the bar. The cute bartender was excited to make a "special" drink for a friend who is a rare drinker and he did not disappoint! 

The chips and salsa- mmmmm delish! The chips literally melt in your mouth in a weird hard to describe way; you can tell they were super fresh! The one item all of us ordered were the empandadas filled with mushrooms, they were just okay. Everything else we all loved! Service was also great! This is a must go if you are in the Union Square area looking for a good place to eat!
author: Ami S.

description: Line is long, which is annoying. But it's long for a reason--the food is great and cheap. I ate the equivalent of three lunches for $20.
author: Faye L.

description:
Next to Press Club, Amber, Schoggi, and the random place with the colored crytal objets d'art, I was expecting yet another pricey restaurant that I would never walk into except for the bar (i.e. another Amber).

Now while their tequila bar isn't open yet, the restaurant is definitely open for lunch and dinner.  I was pleasantly surprised with my fish taco.  It was good - none of that frozen fish stick stuff. I also decided to try their chicken tamale.  And I have to say I dig it.  Real chicken with real cheese sprinkled on top.  Accompanied by a tall glass of horchada, I was quite satiated - all for around $10.  I'm looking forward to going back for dinner and experiencing the magical transformation from lunchtime taqueria to sit down mid-range dining experience.  

Does anyone know what Tropisueno means?
author: Audrey T.

description: Took my cousins here for dinner tonight. What a pleasant experience! I think it really helped that we had reservations. We were seated immediately in a nice quiet little corner, very conversation friendly. The guac was good, we all liked the mint garnish, gave it a little kick. I had a margarita which was mostly tequila. I also had their chicken enchiladas, quite good. Service was excellent and I was thankful for that. Would come again definitely! Love the atmosphere. The nice side of casual.
author: Diana C.

description: Had a late lunch during the changeover from taco bar to happy hour. It wasn't clear how to order, and after a few minutes someone told us to go to the counter and order. You take a number and find a table. 3 of 4 orders actually made it to the table. Meanwhile the ordering area was transformed into walls. It took some time to get the order straight. The food was tasty and prices fair. We will come again, with a little more understanding of how this place works.
author: Steve R.

description:
I was really excited to try Tropisueno after seeing an article on them in 7x7 magazine. That photo of the mole sold me and we even called to see if they could make it vegetarian- they said yes.

Tropisueno has a lot of potential.

 Their salsa is really good but lacks in spicy-ness. It turns out that the mole could not be made veggie bc of the chicken-stock in it. I wish that they would've told us over the phone. booo. Instead we ordered enchiladas and mushroom empanadas. It was pretty decent. I must say the best part of the meal was the sour cream and the drinks. I had a jamaicazo and it was delish. 

I don't think I'll be going back unless it's for happy hour.
author: Alicia V.

description: Great ambience! Good margaritas. Delicious chips and salsas.
author: Sankara R.

description:
Love the food from this place.

The guacamole rocks and the ceviche
is like heaven for me.

The enchiladas I had here were like yummy dumplings of ranchero mexican cuisine.

If you think a Tacqueria is Mexican food don't eat here. 
The have things like refried besn ( and no they are not all made from lard!) 

The lunch lines continue to expand for this place and the chips are the best chips in the city . They keep them piping hot and they are so tasty. You know when the small things taste good they have an eye for detail in terms of food quality. 

I have eaten here 8 times so I considered myself a reliable source for this place. I still have yet to get through half the menu and still come back.
author: Joe R.

description: If you're used to the greasy chimichangas and hefty burritos, you won't enjoy the food too much. The eating experience is close to a lights out kinda dining as you can barely see what you're putting in your mouth. Bottomless taquitos bowls are great and wait time is not too bad.  Start with a glass or two of Duende Margaritas to lower your expectations.
author: Rey Q.

description:
Tropisueño!

If you're dying to get a good look at a great looking bunch of Yelp employees, Tropisueño is the place to go. Seems to be the current lunch hot spot - and for good reason! A deliciously festive alternative to Chipotle and (yes, I'm just gonna go ahead and say it) Chevy's, Tropisueño is quickly securing it's spot among Yerba Buena Lane gems such as the delectable Beard Papa and trendy wine bar Press Club.*

The breaded fish tacos were fresh and light(ish) and are sure to become a lunchtime staple. The other day I went in for a burrito, and it was way too salty for me and didn't come the way it was described on the menu. Seems they are still working out some kinks. But since sauce in it's various forms (including salsa), makes the cut in my top 5 favorite foods, Tropisueño gets extra props for their monstrous salsa bar (with endless lime slices!). I sure am looking forward to the margaritas and checking out the "dramatic" nighttime transformation.

*Sidenote Challenge/Brilliant idea: Spend the day in Yerba Buena lane - Grab some Schoggi Coffee and lil' somethin' for breakfast, pop into the Craft Museum for a while, lunch at Tropisueño, midday Beard Papa dessert/snack, peruse the Jewish Art Museum, dine on some quality Indian eats at Amber, and finish off the night with some mighty fine vino at Press Club. CAN YOU HANDLE IT!??!?!
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I spend most of my workday logged into yelp, checking out one thing or another. Always randomly searching for the next good place to eat...so what on earth took me so long to discover this place??

I've worked in SF for over 8 months (been yelping the whole time) and not once did I come across the name Tropisueno. Only when I specifically searched for Mexican food near Powell did I realize this place existed.

I came here last night with a friend for dinner and was in love. The place is beautiful, tucked gently away in a corner behind the Four Seasons Hotel and across from an old, red-brick church. As we walked in the church bells began to ring, as though in reverence of our arrival. 

We were seated basically wherever we chose, we were the first to arrive for dinner. There is ample seating all over and even a few private booths for larger parties. The lighting was dim and had a slight romantic air to it; even the rainbow string lights across the bar were pleasantly lit so as not to diminish the aesthetic appeal of the area. 

The chips for dipping were amazing! Crunchy, light and warm. I love warm chips, it makes my day. There were 2 types of salsa- one green, the other red. The green was rather tangy and not to my taste, the red was tasty but not spicy at all. Pretty much everything we ate lacked spice. We both ordered the 2 item combo plate for $9.95 (this same plate is even cheaper if you go for lunch!). We tried the enchiladas and tamales. The portions were fairly decent sizes considering the low price we were paying for it. Not quite hot enough (temperature wise) but flavorful and filling nonetheless. 

Overall, I enjoyed the place. Good atmosphere, decent food, prompt water refills (I drink A LOT of water), and unforgettable chips. Ohh the chips...mmmm...I'm giving an extra star for the chips alone!
author: Scooby D.

description: LOVE this place! Such a refreshing menu, amazing drinks and a really fun place for happy hour or dinner. I would recommend the house margarita made with rose...
author: Mallory M.

description: My girlfriend heard about this place and has been wanting to try it for quite some time now. After having some time after holiday shopping, we ventured here to try the food. I ordered the carnitas while she ordered the chicken. Her order was much better than mine. My pork was overall pretty bland and tasteless. I was pretty disappointed The only thing that saved my experience was the strong margaritas and the really tasty chips.
author: Michael N.

description: The place is right around the corner from work, so we often go during lunch.  The decor is fun, nice atmosphere for a friday lunch spot.  The chips and salsa are yum -and the carne asada is good as well.  I've tried the super tacos (carne asada and pollo) and got the quesedilla yesterday.  Not a huge fan of the chicken I think.. will do al pastor super burrito next time I go...and the horchata is so-so.  I'm more used to the $5 for 2 al pastor super tacos in the peninsula, but good spot nonetheless.
author: Melody T.

description: Good food and prices are reasonable for SF! Heads up that you cannot order hh in the dining area. The waitstaff didn't say anything til my group was seated. Recommend getting there early. This place fills up!
author: M C.

description:
LOVE this place.

I love that Tropisueno's sit-down service is an alternative to fast food, hole-in-the-wall Mexican food joints.

I first came here because we had a Restaurant.com coupon. At first I was a bit skeptical since most joints that offer those coupons, offer them because business is suffering (read: food is no good). But boy, was I wrong. Margaritas are excellent, started chips and salsa are delicious. They're both pretty addicting.

Everytime we come here we have to get the pork chop. The meat is so tender and juicy, and falls right off the bone. It's flavored perfectly and the beans, rice, salsa are great compliments that only bring out the flavor of the chop. Must try.

Service is pretty good as well. Decently priced, especially with those coupons. The only thing off is the difficult parking and semi-hidden location. Got lost the first time...
author: Cynthia T.

description: Have again: chicken mole was very good, as were the beans, rice and chips, but the food was not hot (lukewarm), hence only 3 stars instead of 4. Service was good. Very pleasant place, but it was not clear walking in that we ordered at the counter.
author: Keith R.

description: Margaritas were fantastic. All are made with good ingredients and are super refreshing and tart. I stuck with the classic and had no regrets. For dinner, had some of the most amazing chicken enchiladas with mole sauce I have ever had outside of New Mexico.
author: Kristina C.

description: Perhaps it's the salsa and greasy chips but we kinda like Tropisuenos. Chile Verde is some of the best in town and the prices are pretty reasonable for this neighborhood. Always seems busy so recommend reservations even on Monday nights!
author: john h.

description:
I really liked the chips and salsa. It's free and it's yummy! sure beats chevys.
Ordered the carne asada and it was a bit tough.  The taste was ok, but it was just so hard to chew.  It was weird b/c some areas of the steak was ok, while others were so tough to bite into.
The enchillada that came w/ it was good too, except that halfway into the enchillada, it got really really salty and that totally ruined it. 

I will go back to give it another chance. Ambiance wise, it was quite nice.  Came on a Monday and it was pretty quiet.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Good:
Everything(!) available a la carte...
Bring 5 friends; drink for free all night.
Lots of hispanic hipsters for early happy hour = good sign.

Bad:
Kind of low ceilings, but cute design.
author: Melanie C.

description: Fix your happy hour please. I'm sick of showing up here and being unable to get a table. It makes people really grumpy when they get off of work and they can't sit down and have a drink. The rope off empty restaurant is just a slap in the face.
author: Sam G.

description: Decent chicken with mole sauce.  Not much of a dessert list.  The ambiance was festive and fun for a Friday night; the food was just so so.  Good service.
author: B. Y.

description: I was going to give this place a 3, but then I tasted my leftovers from dinner.  The food gets even better when all the flavors get a chance to get to know each other overnight.  The atmosphere was too noisy and dark for me, and everyone was seated super close together, it definitely felt cramped.  On the other hand, the prices are not terrible for the quality and quantity of food, and they give you tons of chips and salsas while you wait to order.  The cocktails look good (I didn't order one) and the service was impressively fast and attentive considering the number of people there.
author: Riva B.

description:
We've been here twice now, and each experience was quite different.   Our first time was for dinner, not many months after they first opened.  The food was quite good.  I had the ropa viejo, and the meat was tasty, well-seasoned, and plentiful.  All entrees off the extensive dinner menu seemed to look delicious.  The decor was upscale but rustic, and the full bar was packed with people.  We ate in the dining room.

We ate here for lunch the second time, and it was like eating at a different place.  The lunch menu is much more limited to things like tacos and burritos.  It is self-order and self-seating, definitely setting a more casual atmosphere.  Figuring out to line up for ordering in the entryway was awkward and confusing.  But mainly the food wasn't nearly as good.  Soft tacos automatically came on corn tortillas, but we prefer flour.  Everything was fresh, but the meat flavors (we had carnitas, carne asada, and chicken) were not very savory, and seemingly under seasoned.  The strong corn flavor of the tortillas overwhelmed everything else.  The tacos looked good, but they weren't delicious in the way a good taco can be.  It's harder to find a good Mexican dinner restaurant in SF than a great taqueria.  If you want delicious, cheap tacos, go to El Farolito in the Mission, it's worth the effort.

I think we'd go back, but for dinner and not for lunch.
author: Dave N.

description:
I cannot say enough good things about this restaurant. The service is more than outstanding and the food is incredibly delicious. And prices are good to boot.

Just go.
author: Gracie S.

description:
Three strikes and you're out.  I went here for my third time with coworkers hoping that they had finally worked out the kinks in the service (a new year, right?) but alas I was wrong.  So near my work but so not worth it.  Horrible service.  Sub-par food.

Today's awful experience:

Coworker 1: Can I get a burrito with Chile Verde?
Tropisueno: What type of meat?
Coworker 1: Umm, chile verde.
Tropisueno: No, what type of meat, chicken or pork.
Coworker 1: Pork

What did the coworker end up with?  Pollo verde.  What the hell?  Chile verde is always pork.  Learn your menu.

Coworker 2: May I please get a super burrito with al pastor.
Tropisueno: (puts pollo asado into tortilla)
Coworker 2: Oh no, pastor please.
Tropisueno: This is pastor.

What did the coworker end up with? Pollo asado.  Actually two of my coworkers ordered pastor and got pollo asado.  Again, learn what's on your menu.

Completely ridiculous.  On top of it, the staff is STILL running around like a chicken with their head cut off.  The management seriously needs to figure out if they're trying to operate a taqueria style place or a real restaurant.  The set-up right now is chaotic and an embarrassment.

Tips of Tropisueno:
Visit ANY taqueria and a) learn to make a decent burrito and b) learn how to properly run a line.  Oh and teach your staff what types of food you serve.
author: Jeff F.

description: I like this spot well enough. It's a bit expensive for a lunch spot (that's when I go). The food was yummy, but I did not enjoy the puddle of grease that was left in my plate...but after that margarita all was well again, lol.
author: James G.

description:
What a nice place! A sweet little sit down restaurant with great ambiance . The mexican options in the SOMA area are typically not that great but this one is definitely an exception!
The food is good and so are the prices :) Great thin chips with hot salsa, wonderful house margaritas, good entree choices, and great great dessert. Not complaining at all!
author: sandhya ..

description:
Right by the back door to the Marriott, this place was ideally located for a quick bite before getting a cab to the Airport. You can't beat nachos and salsa washed down with cold Negra Modelo. The guacamole was fantastically fresh and the quesadilla bursting with tasty carne asada.

I'm sure there are better mexican places in SFO, but I'll certainly come back here next time I'm staying in the neighborhood.
author: Rich B.

description:
To be fair, I enjoyed my burrito. I had a regular with chili verde and refried beans. The woman making it didn't know what chili verde was, and I had to point to the right tub to get what I wanted. But the filling was tasty and generous.

My friends both ordered Al Pastor and got chicken (with pineapple!) - hence disappointment. They also thought the burrito was too wet.

As to price, which a previous reviewer said was cheap -  I paid $7.54 for a regular. That isn't cheap in my book, but maybe if you're used to FiDi prices it qualifies? It's too far from the Mission to be cheap and good.
author: Magnus B.

description:
Very nice atmosphere for a walk-up and order mexican food joint (we ate lunch there, looks like it may turn into a "sit and order" place evenings).  Excellent guac. The ceviché was fresh and zesty, perfect for a warm day.
Veggie tacos were delicious as well!  Staff was super-friendly even on a busy Friday afternoon.  Lovely lunch-time dining experience!
author: Jeffery T.

description:
I like this place. Great margaritas, I wish I had a separate stomach just for the fresh chips and salsa verde.

Plantains and bean appetizer was memorable, tacos were ok, the enchiladas are the kind that feature only a tiny sprinkle of queso fresco on top, which always bugs me.

Never have a problem getting a table here, even with 6 people there's room to drink and snack at the bar.

3 stars because the side dishes are bland
author: Irene P.

description:
This Place is definitely on my GO BACK TO list!!  I've mentioned before I'm very picky when it comes to Mexican food. I grew up in a house where both my mom & dad cooked awesome mexican food. So i'm super dooper picky. 

A co worker suggested we go here for lunch. I asked is it MEXICAN or is it "chipotle/chevy's/aqui" he said "no its good. I think you will like it." Hmmm ok lets go. 
The decor is very awesome. Apparently it's a taqueria by day and restaurant by night. 

so we walk up and yes you order as you go and pay at the end ( they take amex which makes it good for business lunches). You then get a number on the back of a loteria card ( loved the detail) and you go sit down. Some of my co workers had gotten just tacos so their food was ready by the time we paid. I ordered the chile rellenos. I asked for picadillo- but i actually ended up with cheese. HMM however the cheese chiles were so good I didn't go switch them. I was most impressed by the salsa bar. It had Grilled whole jalapenos!!! My favorite I grabbed one and sat down. YIKES the chile was so hot that I immediately became addicted to this place. 

Any Mexican taqueria/restaurant that has the sense to have grilled chiles ready gets my seal of approval!! 

Taqueria prices were cheap. We paid $42 for 5 ppl including sodas! I don't recommend for groups over 6 ppl at lunch time unless you don't mind seating seprately. Combining a bunch of tables to make one  might not work too well. 

I will bump this rating to a 5star once I try the dinners there... if the restaurant is equally good.
author: Mariana M.

description:
This spot is a little awkward and weird for lunch, but at night when it transforms into a real restaurant: woooo. 

It's so nice to find a real sit-down, warm, wonderful Mexican place with perfect margaritas. The atmosphere is on point- soft light, dark colors. The waiters are awesome- quick, friendly, and genuine. The guacamole in the little glass dish that my mom used to give me Pepperidge Farm goldfish in for a snack is okay but it could be better. Im torn on whether or not I like the sharp, thin little chips.
I've had the enchilada and tamales. For dinner- everything was awesome. For lunch they gave me a chicken tamale when I asked for cheese and gave my boyfriend a cheese enchilada when he asked for chicken...which is fine because as far as I know I'm not a vegetarian. 

The house margaritas are made with 100% agave tequila, agave nectar, and fresh lime, Tommy's style. That says something. The glass is rimmed with awesome chili salt. I love it. I love this place. I'm going to go there before class as often as possible and drink $5 Happy Hour drinks, stab my gums with chips, and pray desperately for an actual seat at the packed after-work crowd mobbed bar so I can maybe do a little drunken homework.
author: Sara M.

description:
I've been back here a bunch times for lunch and a couple of times for drinks. I initially compared it to a mission taqueria but I think it deserves more than that, and I live in the mission. The food seems to be getting better every time I go back!! The tequila collection is also very good. The bartender recommended a shot of Corazon that was absolutely delicious! Can't wait to go back!
----------------------
Went here for lunch with a bunch of coworkers. A mission taqueria without the lard AND clean! Perfect!!! I've only been here for lunch but I hear that for dinner it's a different format, like table service and all of that. Will definitely go back, maybe even once a week for lunch!
author: Reza E.

description: I'm a picky mexican food eater, but my oh my do I love me some Tropisueno. I've eaten there twice now and both times were delicious. In fact, this might be my favorite mexican food spot in the city (next to Velvet Cantina). The chips are light and crispy and perfect. The burritos and enchiladas are AMAZING. I mean, I got a bean, rice, and cheese burrito today that far surpassed anything else in the Mission (I know those are some fightin' words!). But seriously, so delicious. Even worth the wait with the douchebag financial district guys being obnoxious behind me in line.
author: Lara M.

description: Best beef burrito ever!  Had to go back for seconds. They make margaritas from scratch with lime juice and agave. Really good happy hour vibe. A must for anyone craving good food, a good vibe and a true margarita experience!
author: Lebni L.

description:
Food = The food was OK. I really think there are quite a few other places in SF to experience better Mexican. The chips, however, were quite tasty.

Service = Incredibly slow! Don't go if you are starving.

Pet Peeve = They charge you for each Diet Coke even though it's coming from the fountain. You are already marking it up 1000%, you seriously can't give me a free refill?
author: Justin A.

description: Yummy! My chile relleno was delicious, huge pepper spilling over with cheese.  The three salsas they give you are super yummy, the green was my fav, all three were empty when we left the table. House margaritas were excellent, the hot salt on the rim was a nice twist. Great price for being right in the heart of SF! Definitely a recommendable location! Thank you for a great meal
author: Shalyce I.

description: closet thing to a mission street burrito in the finicail district..not a fan of chipotle gringo style burritos..if you like more authentic then come here..onlt bad thing is line out the door..always! oh and i only have come here for lunch...
author: Sonia C.

description:
This place is awesome.  The food is top notch and you pay just about as much as you would pay at a place in the mission where  i live.  

DO THE CARNITAS they are epic level.  

The rice is like spanish rice style and the chips are thin thing fresh made and taste great *FREE

next time i go i have to try a margarita.
author: Shawn L.

description: I'm pretty particular when it comes to Mexican food, especially in California. The food here is fantastic and fresh but I was also very impressed with the great care that goes into preparing the takeaway container. Neatly packaged and complete with foil to keep warm and prevent leaking. Smart and delicious!
author: Susan V.

description:
MARGARITAS. I love love love margaritas. Or at least I did, until they betrayed me one Tuesday night. But that's a different story. The margaritas here are so unique and delish. I sip on them slowly to make 'em last longer. Like seriously, you don't fool around with ingredients like lavender, anise, absinthe, etc. It's really an art the way they fuse flavors, and nope it sure doesn't hurt that there's a hottie bartender that works here.

CHIPS. They have such hot, crisp chips that go along with spicy fresh salsa. At happy hour, we get a plate of their nachos, to go with the guac and chips, to go with the salsa and chips. Overkill? I think not.

The steak in my quesadilla was also pretty amazing. An average restaurant would chuck some sub-par quality meat into a quesadilla thinking that the melted cheese and charred tortilla would mask the inferiority, but at Tropisueno they do it big. Not to mention it makes me ten times happier to be paying a happy hour price.

I'm also a sucker for wooden furniture and little lights everywhere. So effin cute. And the place fills up during dinnertime too, so you know it's legit. Come early, leave giddy.
author: Claire C.

description: Taqueria by day, restaurant by night!  I love this place and try to stop here everytime I'm in SF.  Things I love about this place:  1) The salsa bar!  2) The Guacamole (full of fresh red onion and cilantro)! 3) Queso Chile Relleno!  4) The house Margarita on the rocks salted with chili salt!  5) Pork Street Tacos!  6) The Salsa Bar again!  7) The chili salt that rims the house Margarita glass again!  The bar here is excellent... & finally 8) The pork street tacos again!  (The chips are good too).  Plus, you get a lot of good food for a really tiny price.  I would give this little slice of heaven 10 stars if I could.
author: Kari S.

description: This is always my go-to-spot when I am in the mood for Mexican food. The location is convenient if you want to meet your friends in a central location near downtown. I can't get enough of their chips and salsa and I love their tacos. The wait can be a pain so you should make a reservation. If there is a conference in town - forget about it...you can't even get a seat. It's a great lunch spot and I enjoy it for dinner. It's definitely not a hole in the wall but perfect if you want something chill after work.
author: Caroline L.

description:
Had a really nice meal here a few nights back.  We live nearby and had been meaning to try this place for a while.  We came a few days before Christmas, without a reservation.  It was crowded but not packed, so we were able to get in without a wait.

We started with chips and salsa, house margueritas and the shrimp appetizer.  All of them were really good, especially the magueritas (on the rocks, with salt).  For dinner I had the tampiqueno steak, with an enchilada (+ rice) and my wife had the pork adobada.  We both really liked our dishes, and saw several other things on the menu we would like to try.  The service was great.
author: Richard M.

description:
This place tops my list of FAVORITE Mexican food in San Francisco! This place had me at first bite. The chips are so good, served hot and fresh, the salsas... to die for, the tacos... should i keep going ?? 
The concept rocks, taqueria by day and restaurant and bar at night... The owners are great, friendly and so is the staff. Its nice to see a establishment  so dedicated to people really having a good time with great food and drink! I know you haven't seen or heard from me in a while, its because I'm hanging at Tropisueno!
author: Rachel L.

description: I love Tropisueno. If you can make it for their happy hour, the margarita deals are pretty good. Reservations are recommended for dinner. The Camarones Tropisueno is my absolute favorite item. The sauce is delicious! Great ambiance, margaritas and food. One of my favorite sit-down Mexican food places in the city.
author: Reena P.

description:
"Upscale" mexican cuisine nestled into the recently culture-fied Yerba Buena alley. While I wasn't blown away by the food... or the service... or, well, anything really... it was a welcome change from over-priced sit down joints around the area. The ambiance is chill and offers up an ideal place to grab a tequila inspired drink and chow down on a surprisingly reasonably priced menu. 

The food? The appetizer menu offers a better assortment of dishes which were all pretty good. Go with the scallops in chorizo and the carnitas tacos. Delicious and filling. The entree's were far less impressive. The grilled mahi-mahi and the chile verde topped the table favorite list but the self-professed restaurant specialty, camarones tropisueno (shrimp), was a sad version of any shrimp dish found in the mission. 

Go for a drink. Go for a snack. I probably won't purposefully opt to come here again but the food isn't terrible and it's a welcome addition to diversifying the restaurant options for this part of town. 

Plus points for being right in front of the Jewish Contemporary Museum... creates a very visually dynamic eating experience.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Very nice place, good service, food it's not the best but it's ok. My favorite was the carnitas and tacos al pastor! We might come back at dinner and try the margaritas!
author: Norma J.

description:
I was contacted by the owner in a sincere manner and am updating my review because of a misunderstanding about the glasses they use for the margaritas..  apparently they hold the same amount of liquid that a pint glass does.

As for the food sickness: I did get tested almost 3 weeks after the initial sickness to come up negative for the most common food borne illness. My doctor also told me that some people have a bad reaction to ceviche which could be what cause the stomach issue. So I don't know if the issue is "resolved", but for as sincere as the owner may be I'm not sure that the staff who was joking around the whole time and the showboat bartender are on the same page. I know how hard it is to run a business and to find quality help, but all it takes is one person to not wash their hands to hurt someone else.

Original review for transparency:


I'm almost 100% sure this is the place that I got food poisoning from. The night after I ate there I had horrible diarrhea, and it has been about 4 weeks and I'm still not right. I guess we will see what I have when the blood/stool samples I had to give come back tomorrow. I'll update accordingly. The reason I know it was this place is because I went with friends and everyone else got sick in the same way, itd be way too much of a coincidence to say we all got sick from different places at the same time. I guess I just ate more of the "house favorite" ceviche than they did, it messed me up bad for a few days.

As for the service/food: The food was so/so and the margaritas they line up in pint sized glasses and then after making them they pour them into other way smaller glasses..not really worth $5. I had the guacamole, fish tacos, and the ceviche along with some chips.

I will not EVER be returning to this place, I havent been able to drink coffee or alcohol for almost a month now because my stomach is so messed up from whatever bug I caught from this place.
author: Chris S.

description:
A Mexican joint is only as good as its salsa bar. At Tropisueño, you would be better off hiring a guide to take you through the different sauces, diced vegetables, peppers and other accoutrements they provide. I had the grilled chicken burrito with black beans... superb! It had a nice citrus-y flavor and with the extra cilantro and lime I stuck amongst my warm totopos (chips you gringo!), I sat back relaxed and sublimated while I enjoyed my tropical tortilla-wrapped goodness. 

Convenient, close to work, and delicious. Now its nap time. zzzzzzz
author: Sam S.

description:
Great food and service. It was even better because I missed the lunch rush.
There is a line outside at lunch, but it's worth it.
author: JD B.

description: My diet is taking a serious beating here.  Their chicken mole is quite good.  I always eat too much, but it's just too hard to resist.  Serving are large and you get rice, beans, guacamole, salsa and corn tortillas plus chips.  The Sangria is good, too but two drinks cost as much as my entree so I'll try to restrain myself next time.  A good moderately priced, casual place in a good location.
author: Debbie W.

description: Found this little gem hidden away in an alley in the heart of the financial district. High quality Mexican food and unbelievably good service. I don't remember ever being treated this well at a restaurant. The server was extremely friendly and was very helpful at making suggestions. Will never forget her genuine care. Towards the end, the manager came to our table and made sure everything was going well. Make sure you order a side of guacamole. Try the shrimp in brown butter and the carne asada.
author: Wael H.

description:
My Friends an I came here a few weekends ago, walked in around 8:30 and were seated within 10 minutes. For such a large space we were a little taken aback by how few tables were actually there. Waiting for our table we ordered some of the house margaritas from the bar, which were super delicious (and much more potent that I had expected).

Upon being seated we happily started munching away at our bowl of the Most amazing chips you will ever eat. I would probably come here for the chips and margaritas alone, no questions asked. We spent a long time deciding what to order. It was either that the menu was a little too confusing, the lack of real vegetarian options, or we were just too distracted by the amazingly delicious chips (we were on bowl 3 by now). I ordered what was probably a lunch combo plate, but it was rice and beans with a tamale and enchilada. While waiting for our food we continued to munch on chips and order more margaritas, that by the time our food finally arrived none of us were really all that hungry. The food was average, a little dry, and little salty, but still mostly good, but nothing to rave about. 

I would recommend this place for it's drinks and chips, but not for dinner. While we did have a lot of fun here, it is not the kind of place I would want to go when expecting dinner, and especially for the price.
author: Allyson S.

description:
I brought my picky friend here for some tasty margaritas and dinner.   Manuel was more than accomodating when she said she liked her drinks candy sweet.  I tried the house maragarita and was impressed.  The flavors were well balanced and the spiced salt rim added a special touch.  

But the chicken mole stole the show.  My friend had never tried mole before and she was quite impressed.  Chocolate in a sauce?  Heck, yeah.
author: Monica L.

description: Tropisueno is exceptional -- Mission Taqueria prices, excellent (fresh, expertly-prepared) food (Creek stone farms steak, Neiman Ranch pork etc.)  and an unbelievable Margarita menu (agave tequila +French liquors + fresh lime juice and artisanal salt = amazing), all served up in a lovely setting.   This place is an absolute gem -- perfect for budget-conscious foodies.
author: Jessica E.

description:
My friend had the chile verde, and I had the tampiqueno.  My meal was good, but the chile verde was excellent.  I would definitely recommend this place.  They had warm chips!!

One thing to note:  I went back again for lunch, and it was not as good as dinner!
author: C L.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Friday night...place was still packed!

*Chicken with Mole Poblano 
*Fresh Mahi Mahi en la Parilla
*Ceviche de Pescado
*Camarones Tropisueno
Carne Asada
Pollo Asado
CHIPS + salsa...amazing
dos equis amber....
3 varieties of beans and tortillas

* our favorites

Service is awesome....totally nice....they love offering shots to birthday guests! We were one of the last tables there that night so they didn't have a million other tables to attend to.

COMING BK FOR HAPPY HOUR!
author: Kelley N.

description:
So, I've been holding out on reviewing Tropisueno because I was really hoping that they'd work out their service issues. The first few times, I chalked it up to the restaurant being new. It's been a few months, and I've eaten lunch here multiple times, and I can no longer give them the benefit of the doubt.

The food is 4 stars. As far as I'm aware, it's the best Mexican at this price point in the neighborhood. I particularly like their barbacoa, which I've enjoyed on nachos, on a tostada, and as a taco. Guac is solid, and the chips are pretty delicious without being super-greasy. 

But the service. 2 stars. It's almost like stepping into the twilight zone -- often, there's no line, but it still takes 5-10 minutes for someone to take your order (even if you go after the lunch rush). I'll keep my fingers crossed that they'll shape up, and I'll probably still frequent the place. What can I say -- I love me some barbacoa.
author: Marisa F.

description:
Update: Finally went here for Happy Hour since a friend had given me these passes for $2 margaritas. Having been there before and had the margaritas and not wanting to stop drinking them, I was excited to go back and have more at a cheaper price (during the day they are verrry expensive).  

Maybe it was just our experience, but HH there sucked. The staff was un-attentive, they brought us out chips and salsa and then we saw that we were charged $2 for them. The worst part that they don't tell you..the margaritas are different than the day time..they use different stuff to make them. My buddy and I both agreed that they were by far the worst margaritas we've had...and we drink a lot. 

HH was a let down, but lunch will hopefully stay good. I guess you just have to pay for better drinks.
author: Joe U.

description: Aw man, I totally ADORE this place!  Reminds me of Mexico. Cute little lamp things decorated across the room gives this place a festive flavor. I also should mention the cheap happy hour drinks - $5 for strawberry margaritas and free chips and salsa! The sauces included with the chips were tasty. I especially like the orange colored spicy dipping sauce. I wanted to bottle up a jar to take home. The grilled fish tacos were yummy too. The Mexican waiters were fast, friendly, and accommodating. Will come back EARLY next time before the happy hour crowd hits.
author: Kelly C.

description: This place is ok, the location is convenient and its spacious. But I found the food to be bland and a bit OLD.  I order the chile relleno plate - the rice & beans looked and tasted like they had been on the counter for hours.  One orders as if you're at a taco stand off this kind of obnoxious large wall menu.  The salsa bar was good but tucked in weird corner. And I found the drinks to be tasty but nothing spectacular.  For the price I'd rather have table service.  I'd return with tourist friends but I don't think I'd say it was remarkable.
author: Sandra P.

description: Great food and always fun! Staff is very friendly. Endless salsa is the best!
author: Anna K.

description:
Fantastic food! 
For $10-15 per person, this place rocks! It is better than moderately priced but I wouldn't call it cheap because its not, its inexpensive. 
The food is amazing and pretty generously portioned. We had a table of 5 and ordered way too much food but of course, it was so good, we overate. The sea scallops are amazing and the guacamole is definitely worth ordering. 
The entrees are huge and really tasty- I wish we could have tried more! 
The service was very attentive (almost too much) but they read our needs and did a great job. 
Be weary that the place is pretty loud when its full, which is usually is. Not a great place for a timid first date but more than exceptional for a party of friends! 
I will be back!
author: Janell D.

description:
We usually have a good time at Tropisueno, but yesterday was a disaster! We had the worst waitress on the planet. Beware of Rosa!! She had an attitude every time we asked for something. I asked her for water twice, she never brought it. Thank God Roman, not our waiter, was sweet enough to get the whole table water. Since happy hour was winding down we felt like we were being pushed out. We ordered a round of drinks from another waiter, didn't catch his name, and they never came. Rosa came to our table and was yelling at us telling us that happy hour was over and it was gonna be full price. We didn't mind, we had money to pay for them. Well instead she brought our bill,we paid it and left. I didn't talk to the manager about because I just wanted to leave! We were amazed at how terrible the service was. We probably won't be returning back. :( 
It's sad because the food is awesome, the drinks are yummy and some of the waiters, like Roman, are actually really cool.
author: Annette S.

description: Hate to say this! Ate there last last week!  I had beef & chicken enchiladas . Looks good then I got sick for 2-1/2 days cramping stomach, bathroom 20x ..couldn't go to my doctor. Stay on the bathroom almost 24 hours . It was so bad. I will never eating there again. I call this morning to report what happen! Host answer . And told her can I speak to the manager? She said manager is busy.  Incident like this they should give priority ?  I felt bad.. I'm the one got sick on their food. Seems they don't care ? Good luck....
author: bien m.

description:
We found this place through yelp, as we were looking for a decent bite before seeing a movie at the Metreon.

The food was very good!
From the chips/salsa to the beef enchiladas, everything was tasty.

Not too expensive, atmosphere was nice...
will go back again!

Recommended.
author: Megan M.

description: This is a great spot for lunch & dinner. I usually come in here for dinner in the middle of the week to get the Camarones Tropisueno. yummmmmmmm
author: Motaz H.

description: At the moment my memory is failing me and I can only recall a few things that we had during dinner. In my defense the main point of the meal was catching up with friends and drinking margaritas... The delicious food was a great bonus though! Hands down the highlight of the meal for me was the Ceviche de Camaron. Thanks menupages for giving me the name of the scrumptious shrimp dish that we shared! Next time I go back I'm just going to get two orders of this for myself instead of an entree!! Even if the rest of the food wasn't delicious I would still give Tropisueno 5 stars because of the shrimp. It was that good! The guacamole was excellent as were the tacos that we ordered. Lastly the house margaritas are good and really strong!
author: Chrissy D.

description:
best mexican food in the city
lost one star because their location sucks and it's so hard to get out there.  also the host/hostess makes you wait forever even with multiple open tables.
food is still the best.  except for poc chuc, but they don't call themselves Mexican.
author: reza n.

description:
Chevy's 2.0
Overrated!!

It gets crowded with convention attendees (you can see the trade show badges around their necks), so service and food preparation gets sloppy.

If you're not afraid of the Mission area, go there to get better tasting food for LESS.
author: George M.

description: If you are looking for "Mexican Food" do not go to Tropisueno. Not that what they serve is terrible but it is American Mexican style food. I found the food very bland and nothing more than adequate. I was meeting a friend who was flying in and her plane was a little late. I had a 7:00 PM Reservation and I showed up at 7:00. They promptly told me that I could only have my table for two hours. I saw as I was there for a while that they actually had someone going around the place timing the tables. I thought that sucked. I ordered a Pacifico and what they brought me out was like a bud light. Wrong color and definitely wrong taste. I sent it back and they brought me another that was closer but not Pacfico. I see many reviews about the chips and salsa. The chips are a little too gourmet for me but not bad. The three salsas again are not real mexican salsa but more of a sauce. Again not terrible but not what I was expecting. Spending my whole life in San Diego I know my Mexican food and this is not it. For a City with so many great places to eat we are seriously lacking on the Mex side. The service was attentive and professional but it just seemed like we were eating in a production line. Get your food, eat it quick and get out. I am not a fan.
author: Steve E.

description:
Whoa this place is good!! Tonight was my 1st time here and I hate to admit it but all the food here was soo good that my boyfriend and I polished off 3 bowls of chips and salsa alone! The chips are thin and flaky and the salsa delicious! 
I ordered the plantains as a starter (umm...awesome!!) and the chicken mole. I like to order these two things a lot in places and this was the best mole I've had in SF. The chicken meat practically fell off the bone and the mole was not too starchy and was v. flavorful. My only "complaint" (if you can call it that) was that I like the margaritas at Tres Agaves better and they were quite pricey here (avg. $9/drink). I recommend giving this place a try if you're a Tres Agaves regular. You'll be pleasantly surprised. I promise. :)
author: Kim B.

description: This place is great. It's better for lunch than dinner but dinner is still good. Great prices and very solid Mexican food.
author: Johanna W.

description:
Was craving some Mexican food for lunch today and since Trop is so close to the office, I decided to give it another shot. I did decide to play it safe and ordered a super pollo verde quesadilla. I figured no reputable place can really screen this up!

This cost me $8.08 and was actually quite a bit of food. They packed a lot of meat into the tortilla and gave a big helping of sour cream, guacamole, salsa and shredded iceberg on the side. 

Once again, the service was pretty good aside from a fairly long wait to get the food. And once again, the woman who took my order seemed a little confused when I told her I wanted pollo verde. 

Just like last time, the flavors just seemed bland. Everything seems toned down so there are no complaints of food being too spicy. Perhaps I just like more flavorful food than most? I am not sure.
author: Jason B.

description:
All I have to say is Holy Mole!

This could very well be the best traditional mexican restaurant I've tried in the city so far.  Mind you, this ain't no Chevy's.  Tisk tisk for the comparison!  The ladies and I met up for our usual pow wow dinner.  We ordered:
- Fried sweet plantains
- Chile Relleno de Picadillo
- Chile Verde which is tender pork simmered in yummies
- Chicken with Mole Poblano
- Los Favoritos - Pick your plate

Everything, I mean everything, was delicioso!  The best plantains I've ever tasted!

Service was a little slow (forgot my drink), but super nice.  The place was packed on a week night after happy hour.  I recommend making reservations if you don't want to wait.  Great ambiance, very decent prices.  

I'll be going back fo sho!
author: Stella K.

description: Amazing Chips and Salsa! I Mean that's half the fun of going out for Mexican food and Tropisueno has a trio of Delicious salsas that i just adore. I went here with a bigger group with no reservation and we were able to find a seat at the bar so it all worked out. Our server Roman was so great and really helped us choose some appetizers to share we got the Ceviche, Scallops and guacamole. Everything was perfectly seasoned and very fresh tasting so i was happy! The drinks here are beyond yummy and the Bartender made me a jalapeno martini that was so unique that i am craving it now. Definitely come here you will not be disappointed.
author: Jessica M.

description: Food was OK, but service was not good. They do "family style" dining with the beans and tortillas, but then brought us hardly any of either for a group of 5. We asked for more tortillas, but there was still not enough to go around. Also, when you order a soda it comes in a small bottle (with a glass if you want it), but no refills which is kind of cheap, I think. Finally, it was probably the loudest restaurant I have ever been in. Couldn't hear myself think!
author: Sunshine M.

description: A definite hidden gem. A group of us went for a rushed dinner one night during WWDC and it was great!
author: john W.

description: Went back to this place for lunch. Loved the lunch set up. Sort of cafeteria style but the food was warm and excellent and delivered in less than 10 mins to our table. Guac not as good as dinner for some reason but I'm a fan of this place for people who like mexican food. Veggie burrito is one of the better ones I've had.
author: Michael S.

description: My wife and I went last October after the Nike Women's Marathon.  Best Chicken Mole I've had.  Also loved the 3 different salsa's.  Can't wait to come back to SF and try something else.
author: Grant S.

description:
Lunch time here kicks ass! The prices are similar to that of a taqueria, but the food quality is of a nice restaurant... because it is a nice restaurant! The carne asada not only LOOKS delicious with all it's spices and marination, but IS delicious. 

The service gets 5 stars as well. I can't remember I saw such nice employees everywhere. There was a guy cleaning around the salsa cart, and he was just so friendly and nice! He even poured the sauces for me, and humored me with some spanish. 

Make sure you get the bright orange sauce in the cart- it's on the spicier side, but kicks total ass. If any of you know what La Vics orange sauce is, it is similar to it, but not the same. 

Even though they got my order wrong the first time was there, I still give this place 5 stars. I have an arsenal of food in downtown SF to choose from, but I have went here for the past 3 days in a row.
author: Shaddie J.

description:
